LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY
Borrower : The Republic of Indonesia
Project Description : The  Project  will  promote  sustainable  management  of
natural  resources  for  environment  protection  and
socioeconomic  development  under  a  decentralized
framework  of  government  in  15  provinces.  This  will  be
achieved  by:  (i)  strengthening  the  local  capacity  for
sustainable  planning  and  management  of  marine  and
coastal  resources,  (ii)  improving  the  availability  of  and
access to quality spatial and biodiversity information and
data useful for resource planning, (iii) improving the legal
and  regulatory  framework  in  resource  management  and
compliance  with  it,  and  (iv)  undertaking  small-scale
investments  for  improving  socioeconomic  and
environmental conditions in selected coastal habitats.
Classification : Primary - Environmental protection
Environmental Category  B
Assessment An initial environmental examination (IEE) was undertaken,
and the summary IEE is included as a core appendix.
Rationale : Marine and coastal resources provide important support to
Indonesia's  economy,  and  are  of  national  and  global
importance  because  of  their  rich  biological  diversity.
However, current management efforts do not adequately
meet the objectives for protection and sustainable use of
coastal  resources.  Resource  use  and  exploitation  have
resulted  in  widespread  environmental  degradation.  The
present situation can be largely attributed to lack of (i)  an
integrated  approach  to  coastal  zone  planning  and
management, (ii) information and data on which to base
resource  management  decisions,  (iii)  transparency  in
resource  allocation,  and  (iv)  local  government  and
community  involvement  in  resource  management.  The
pressure  on  marine  and  coastal  resources  has  been
exacerbated by financial and economic crises. Resource
depletion  and  environmental  degradation  have  adversely
affected  coastal  communities,  particularly  the  artisanal
fishers.
The recent political changes have ushered in a new phase
for  natural  resources  management  and  environmental
protection. The Government has initiated a decentralization
process  whereby  natural  resource  management
responsibilities are being devolved to local governments,
which will have a larger share of revenues under new fiscal
arrangements.  The  process  increases  the  sense  of
ownership  of  resources  at  the  local  level,  provides
opportunities for community participation, and enhances the
prospect for transparency in resource allocation. However,

I.  THE PROPOSAL
1. I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed
loan to the Republic of Indonesia for the Marine and Coastal Resources Management Project.
The  Report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  for  Capacity  Building  for
Decentralized Natural Resources Management, and if the proposed loan is approved by the
Board, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, shall approve such technical
assistance.
II.  INTRODUCTION
2. A  feasibility  study  of  the  Marine  and  Coastal  Resources  Management  Project  was
carried out in 1998-1999 under ADB technical assistance (TA).1 The study examined resource
planning  and  management  issues  to  identify  the  causes  of  marine  and  coastal  resources
degradation, and prepared an investment program for enhancing the institutional capacity of the
relevant national and regional agencies and local communities for sustainable management of
resources.  At  the  request  of  the  Government,  an  ADB  Loan  Fact-Finding  Mission  visited
Indonesia from 27 March to 18 April 2000, followed by an Appraisal Mission2 from 17 July to 8
August  2000. This Report is based on the findings of the ADB Missions, a review of various
studies including the feasibility studies of the Project, the Mangrove Rehabilitation Project,3
Natural Resources and Environmental Management Sector Project,4 and National Biodiversity
Information Network Project,5 and discussions with national and regional government officials
concerned, members of civil society, and coastal and small island communities. The project
framework is in Appendix 1.
III.  BACKGROUND
A.  Sector Description
1. Marine and Coastal Resources Sector
3. Indonesia is the world’s largest archipelagic nation, with a marine area of 5.8 million
square kilometers (km2), comprising 3.1 million km2 of territorial and archipelagic seas and 2.7
million km2 of exclusive economic zone. In contrast, its landmass totals only 1.9 million km2.
With a coastline covering 81,000 km and 17,508 islands, Indonesia is truly a maritime continent,
with a vast mass of water surrounding small pockets of land. The marine and coastal areas are
rich in natural resources consisting of rich and diverse living aquatic resources and significant
reserves of oil, gas, and other minerals. Indonesia’s marine waters cover important maritime
routes and offer opportunities for development of maritime service industries. In 1997, the total
product of coastal and marine economic activities was estimated at some 25-30 percent of
Indonesia’s gross domestic product (GDP), providing employment for about 20 million people.

4. Despite  the  importance  of  coastal  and  marine  waters  to  Indonesia’s  economy  and
environment, this resource has not been managed sustainably. Resource use and exploitation
have led to extensive coastal zone degradation — loss of mangrove forests, destruction of coral
reefs, depletion of fish stocks, water pollution, soil erosion, and biodiversity loss. About 30
percent of Indonesia’s 4.3 million hectares (ha) of coastal mangrove forests, a biologically and
economically important ecosystem, has been lost since the mid-1960s. The loss is mostly due
to forestry concession operations, and conversion to fishponds, rice fields, industrial estates,
and settlements. The rapid loss of mangrove cover has exacerbated shoreline erosion, led to
destruction of natural habitats for demersal fish and shrimp, increased the occurrence of saline
water intrusion into freshwater aquifers, and affected the livelihood of coastal fishers. Most of
the coral reefs are rapidly deteriorating, mainly because of intensive human activities, such as
coral mining, blast and cyanide fishing, sedimentation, tourist activities, coastal development,
and pollution. Using a measure of live coral cover, a national survey in 1994 found that only 30
percent remained in good to excellent condition. Since 1994, global warming and associated
coral bleaching, plus increased reliance on coastal fishing, have further damaged the nation’s
reefs.  Since coral reefs are habitats of about 90 percent of the fish caught by the coastal fishers
in the country, their degradation results in rapid decrease of fisheries production in coastal
areas.
5. The coastal environment has also been affected by land-based activities. Watershed
deforestation and erosion have led to increased sedimentation in estuaries, adversely affecting
navigation routes, mangrove forests, coral reefs, and fisheries resources. Industrial and urban
wastes and runoff, containing chemicals and pesticides from agricultural land, have polluted
coastal waters and impaired the ecological functions of coastal habitats as nursery and breeding
grounds for marine aquatic resources.
6. The degradation of aquatic habitats, accompanied by overfishing, has depleted fisheries
resources. An ADB-assisted study6 confirmed serious depletion of fisheries resources in the
coastal regions of Sumatra, North Java, and the straits of Malacca and Makassar. Although the
overall current marine capture fisheries harvest level at 3.08 million tons (t) is believed to be
below the estimated maximum sustainable yield of 4.5 million t,7 catches of certain commercial
species such as shrimp have exceeded their sustainable yield levels.
7. Degradation of coastal and marine resources poses a serious threat to Indonesia’s rich
and unique marine biodiversity. Indonesia has about 20,000 species of mollusks, 2,000 species
of crustaceans, 6 species of sea turtles, 30 marine mammal species, and over 8,500 fish
species. No comprehensive survey has been carried out in recent years to assess the current
state of these living aquatic resources, but it is believed that continued stress threatens the
existence of many species. To protect marine biodiversity, the Government planned to identify
and designate 30 million ha for marine conservation by the year 2000; but only 2.5 million ha
has so far been identified and is being conserved. Major impediments in establishing marine
reserves  were  lack  of  understanding  of  conservation  values  among  the  planners  and
implementors in an inappropriate former Ministry of Forestry and Estate Crops (MOFEC).
8. Natural resources degradation and environmental problems in the coastal zone have
affected the livelihood of coastal people, particularly artisanal (small-scale) fishers. Artisanal
fishing is the occupation of last resort for many poor people in the country due to the population
growth, decreased availability of farmland, and open access to sea. Consequently, the number

2. Planning and Management Framework
a.  Legal Framework
9. The Indonesian Constitution requires that natural resources be managed to achieve the
greatest possible benefit for the people.  A number of relevant laws drafted with the assistance
of international experts were passed by the legislature. Among them are (i) Forestry Act of
1967, (ii) Environment Act No. 4 of 1982, (iii) Fisheries Act No. 9 of 1985, (iv) Conservation of
Living Resources and their Ecosystems Act No. 5 of 1992, (v) Spatial Planning Act No. 24 of
1992; and (vi) Environmental Management Act No. 23 of 1997. In addition, Indonesia is a
signatory to a number of international declarations on natural resources and environmental
management,  and  issued  laws  ratifying  some  of  these  declarations.  They  include  (i)  UN
Convention of the Law of the Sea (1982); (ii) International Maritime Organization laws on marine
pollution (1969, 1971, 1989); and (iii) UN Convention on Biodiversity (1992). These laws have
been supplemented by regulations setting out basic sector policies, for example, on mining,
fisheries,  forestry,  and  environment.  Also,  there  are  customary  local  laws  governing  the
allocation and use of natural resources, but these laws are hardly observed.
10. The many agencies involved in the multiple use of marine and coastal areas are not
properly  coordinated.  Many  resource  management  issues  were  addressed  by  ministerial
decrees, which covered only part of the solution because the ministry concerned had limited
jurisdiction. Often these ministerial decrees concerning marine space were inconsistent with one
another and hence difficult to implement. Spatial Planning Act No. 24 of 1992 was aimed at
reducing conflicts over the use of land and sea resources by providing a strong legislation for
resource allocation and management based on spatial considerations. However, institutional
weaknesses and lack of political will have failed to sufficiently institutionalize the spatial planning
concept in managing marine and terrestrial resources.
11. Enforcement of laws and regulations is weak largely because of lack of transparency
and weak institutional capability. Many resource allocation and resource use decisions were
taken at high levels of Government without considering resource sustainability and adherence to
legal provisions.   Such decisions were frequently made without adequate consultation with local
governments and the affected communities.
12. Regional Autonomy Act No. 22 of 1999 provides a new dimension to the legal framework
of natural resources planning. The Act aims to decentralize most Government services and
devolve the planning and management functions and responsibilities of marine and coastal
resources within Indonesia’s territorial waters to the provincial and district governments. The Act
provides incentives to local governments for sustainable management of natural resources
within their respective jurisdiction, and requires a revision of some existing laws and regulations
to bring them into harmony with it.

4
b. Institutional Framework
13. A large number of Government agencies and institutions are involved in planning and
managing  natural  resources,  including  marine  and  coastal  resources.  These
agencies/institutions can be grouped into three categories: (i) information and data producers,
(ii) data coordinators, and (iii) data users.
i.  Information and Data Producers
14. The main information and data producers and suppliers are the following:
(i)  Agency for National Space and Aeronautics, mandated, among others, to receive
and process satellite imagery on terrestrial and marine resources;
(ii)  Center for Oceanographic Research and Development, mandated to undertake
research and collect data relating to oceanology, marine biology, and marine
environment;
(iii)  Central Research Institute for Fisheries, responsible for conducting research on
fisheries and other living aquatic resources;
(iv)  Marine Geological Institute, mandated to conduct geological and geophysical
surveys and research, and publish the findings; and
(v)  National  Hydrographic  Service,  which  is  the  national  authority  for  collecting
bathymetric data and preparing nautical charts and navigational publications.
15. In addition, a number of ministries and agencies collect marine and coastal resource
data essentially for their own immediate use in planning specific development activities. The
most important among these are (i) Ministry  of  Marine  Affairs  and  Fisheries  (MMAF),  (ii)
Ministry of Home Affairs and Regional Autonomy (MOHA), (iii) Ministry of Communication, (iv)
Directorate General of Tourism, (v) State Ministry of Environment (LH), and (vi) National Agency
for Environmental Impact Management (BAPEDAL).
ii.  Data Coordinators
16. The  Agency  for  Assessment  and  Application  of  Technology  (BPPT)  and  National
Coordinating  Agency  for  Survey  and  Mapping  (BAKOSURTANAL)  play  important  roles  in
coordinating data collection and dissemination. BPPT is the owner of three marine survey
vessels—Baruna Jaya I, II, and III—which provide support to all agencies involved in marine
data collection. BAKOSURTANAL coordinates national activities in topographic and natural
resources surveys, and produces and disseminates digital and hardcopy maps. The agency has
a division of marine mapping, which develops and evaluates the results of marine surveys and
tidal monitoring.
iii. Data Users
17. The  data  users  are  the  national  and  regional  development  planning  agencies
(BAPPENAS and BAPPEDAs), Government line agencies, private investors in fisheries, tourism
and  sea  communication,  and  educational  institutions.  BAPPENAS  formulates  the
macroeconomic  framework  within  which  the  substance  and  scale  of  sector  programs  are
determined. BAPPENAS uses highly aggregated data, much of which is denominated in value
rather than physical terms. However, as the pressure on physical space and concerns about
environmental  quality  increase,  the  spatial  implications  of  economic  planning  are  now
emphasized.  Provincial and district BAPPEDAs are major users of resource data. Other users

5
among Government agencies include the Directorates General of Fisheries, Forestry, Rural
Development,  and  Sea  Communication,  and  the  National  Law  and  Development  Agency
(BPHN). BPHN has a database for laws, decrees, and regulations relevant to marine resources
both for the agency’s own purposes and for dissemination.
c. Planning Framework
i.  National Planning
18. At  the  national  level,  natural  resources  planning  involves  the  formulation  of  a
macroeconomic framework where individual sector goals are established and then translated
into  budgetary  requirements.  The  principal  mode  of  implementation  has  been  a  25-year
perspective plan and successive five-year plans. Within the framework of five-year plans, overall
development policy priorities are coordinated by BAPPENAS. In the past, national development
policy formulation was undertaken in the context of macroeconomic development that, in turn,
was translated into a regional economic approach. This often led to a planning system that
overlooked resource sustainability.
19. Over the last decade, there has been a shift in emphasis, and the Government initiated
measures for resource evaluation and their accounting in preparing development plans. The
measures include implementing specific programs and projects to enhance the capabilities of
concerned Government agencies for data acquisition and exchange, and resource assessment.
The programs and projects include Regional Physical Planning Program for Transmigration, the
ADB-assisted  Land  Resource  Evaluation  and  Planning  Project  (LREP),8  Second  Land
Resources Evaluation Project (LREP II),9 Marine Resources Evaluation and Planning Project
(MREP),10 Coastal Community Development and Fisheries Resources Management Project,11
and Coral Reef Rehabilitation and Management Project (COREMAP),12 and the United States
Agency  for  International  Development  (USAID)-assisted  Natural  Resources  Management
Program (NRMP). An important contribution of these programs and projects is the heightened
awareness  created  among  the  planners  and  implementors  concerned  of  the  need  for
sustainable use of resources. However, they covered only a small part of Indonesia’s land and
marine areas, and much more efforts will be required to develop a comprehensive database and
physical plans for managing the country’s marine and terrestrial resources.
ii. Sector Planning
20. Sector planning at the national level is the responsibility of individual ministries. A major
weakness in sector planning for natural resources, including marine and coastal resources, is
the  absence  of  adequate  information  on  which  to  base  resource  management  decisions.
Another weakness is the inability to identify intersector conflicts of interest for the same space.
This can be avoided through spatial planning, which provides a framework for identifying such
conflicts, selecting optimal use of the space, and allocating the use rights to the authorized
users.

iii. Provincial and District Planning
21. Provincial and district planning is the responsibility of the respective BAPPEDAs at
provincial and district levels. Provincial BAPPEDA is responsible to the governor for overall
planning at the provincial level and for coordinating sector plans prepared by provincial services
of sector agencies. While BAPPEDA is referred to as a planning agency, in reality its role has so
far heavily focused on regional coordination of sector development initiatives. As the bulk of the
public expenditures funding has been controlled by central agencies, resource development
planning at provincial level has been essentially centrally directed. Nonetheless, ADB- and other
aid-assisted projects in the natural resources evaluation and planning projects have assisted
many provincial BAPPEDAs in developing human resources and strengthening the capacity for
effective planning. Significantly greater capacity building efforts are now required to prepare
BAPPEDAs  for  shouldering  the  significantly  greater  planning  functions  and  responsibilities
devolved to them under Regional Autonomy Act 22 of 1999.
B.  Government Policies and Plans
22. In recent years, Indonesia has embarked on a series of reforms in social, political, and
economic areas as well as in Government processes and institutions. The new Government's
strategic  priorities  emphasize  national  unity,  macroeconomic  policies  to  support  economic
recovery, poverty reduction, agricultural and rural development, support for small and medium-
size enterprises, decentralization, and good governance. State Policy Guidelines for 1999-2000
dictate that natural resources should be managed to ensure that their carrying capacity is
preserved for the welfare of present and future generations, and to protect the national wealth of
biodiversity. The guidelines require enacting legislation to provide for the gradual delegation of
authority for managing natural resources to the local level. It gives special attention to the
empowerment  of  local  communities,  traditional  institutions,  and  nongovernment  institutions
(NGOs) for natural resources management. National development agenda and sector strategies
are to be formulated and reflected in a new five-year National Development Program (Propenas
2001-2005) based on national guidelines.
23. Recognizing the potential of the marine area and its status as a common global property,
the  Government  declared  improved  marine  resource  management  as  a  priority  of  the
administration.  The Government created  MMAF in 1999, with a pronounced vision of the sea
as  the  nation’s  future.    The  sector  policy  statement  covers  (i)  efficient  and  sustainable
management  of  maritime  resources,  (ii)  rehabilitation  of  damaged  coastal  and  marine
ecosystems,  (iii)  sustainable  development  of  coastal  zone  and  territorial  waters  through
improved  spatial  planning,  (iv)  improvement  of  resource  database  and  modernization  of
information  and  data  exchange  and  dissemination  facilities,  (v)  improvement  of  the
socioeconomic conditions of the coastal community, and (vi) promotion of the maritime concept
to the public and all stakeholders.
24. The Government has reassigned the task of establishing and managing 30 million ha of
marine conservation areas from the former MOFEC to MMAF. The marine reserves are to be
established  in  accordance  with  the  Biodiversity  Action  Plan  of  1993.  Lack  of  appropriate
expertise in MOFEC previously hampered the establishment of the marine reserves. Within
MMAF, a Directorate General of Sea Surveillance and Protection was established exclusively
for  protecting  marine  reserves  and  enforcing  laws  and  regulations  in  harvesting  marine
resources.

29. Of the 16 ADB-financed loan projects in the sector, 13 have been completed and 3 are
in various stages of implementation. Of the completed projects, eight have been post-evaluated:

into account in designing the proposed Project. Experience gained in three other ADB-financed

1. Project Management and Implementation
30. Major factors that adversely affect project management and implementation include a
multiplicity of executing agencies (EA), lack of coordination among the participating agencies,
lack  of  qualified  staff,  and  delays  in  engaging  consultants  and  procuring  equipment  and
materials. All three similar projects in the sector, (LREP, LREP II, and MREP) were affected to
varying degrees by the above factors. The Project will be managed by a single EA, MMAF.
MMAF has subsumed the functions and responsibilities of a number of agencies previously
responsible  for  the  sector.  To  coordinate  the  inputs  of  all  implementing  agencies  (IAs),  a
technical team will be established in MMAF with qualified staff deputed by the IAs on a full-time
basis. MMAF is expected to have the full staff complement by the time project implementation
commences in early 2001. Some of these staff may lack requisite experience and will need
training to effectively contribute to project implementation.  Similarly, provincial and district
BAPPEDA  staff,  who  will  play  a  key  role  in  resource  planning  activities,  lack  adequate
experience and will require training. The project design provides for extensive training of staff of
MMAF, BAPPEDAs and other agencies to enhance their knowledge base and skills.
2.  Project Ownership
31. Development priorities determined at central level often result in lack of ownership at the
regional level and impede project implementation and achievement of objectives. Care has
been taken to develop project ownership by involving the regional governments and institutions
in  project  preparation  and  incorporating  their  views  and  priorities  in  project  design  and
implementation arrangements. This is reflected in the project scope, which includes, unlike in
MREP, a component for implementing small-scale natural resources management schemes to
be identified in the management plans for the priority marine and coastal management areas
(MCMAs)  in  the  participating  provinces.  The  MCMAs  were  selected  by  the  provinces  and
districts concerned, rather than the national sector agencies, following a set of agreed-upon
selection criteria. Field-level implementation of project activities will be by provincial and district
BAPPEDAs  and  sector  agencies  concerned,  with  MMAF  acting  primarily  as  facilitator  and
coordinator. Project ownership at the local level has been further enhanced by the ensuing
administrative and fiscal decentralization, which will also require local governments to share
funding responsibility for the Project with the national Government.
3.  Private and Community Participation
32. Adequate private and community participation in design and implementation enhances
transparency and efficiency of project implementation and improves sustainability. The Project
will therefore encourage qualified private entities, in addition to Government agencies, to supply
resource data on a competitive basis. This will be a departure from the previous practice of
carrying out mostly similar activities through force account contracts by government agencies.
The Project will provide for a public participation program, to be established within BAPPEDAs,
to discuss the sequence of spatial plans during their preparation and implementation; and for a
review of laws and regulations relating to allocation, use, and management of natural resources,
and their enforcement. Priority site-specific development activities, identified in the district action
plans, will be planned and implemented largely by local communities, with technical guidance
provided by NGOs, and local government technical agencies.

33. In a multilocation and multicomponent project, prior assessment of data and information
needs for resource planning is not feasible, and predetermined data needs often result in waste

E.  ADB’s Sector Strategy
34. ADB’s operations in Indonesia since the recent financial crisis have been guided by an
interim operational strategy (IOS). Covering the period 1998-2000, the strategy emphasizes
governance reform (especially anticorruption, decentralization, and corporate governance) in
the  financial  and  key  real  and  social  sectors,  support  to  social  safety  nets  and  social
development, sustainable resource management, and rehabilitation of physical infrastructure. A
new country operational strategy (COS) is being prepared, and poverty reduction, balanced
regional  development,  good  governance,  and  sustainable  resource  management  and
environmental protection are expected to be major priorities.
35. Within the framework of IOS, ADB’s assistance to the marine and coastal resources
sector in Indonesia focuses on resource evaluation, planning, and sustainable management;
environmental  protection;  development  of  human  resources;  and  support  for  decentralized
resource management. The sector activities are also guided by ADB’s fisheries policy,13 which
emphasizes developing appropriate policy and institutional environment and capacity building to
enable its developing member countries to optimize utilization and sustainable management of
fisheries and aquatic resources. ADB’s strategy for the fisheries sector is anchored on three
basic objectives: (i) sustainability in conserving and utilizing aquatic resources; (ii) equity in
balancing the interests of competing users; and (ii) eficiency in developing and managing
aquatic resources.  The private sector and local communities are expected to play a central role
in  production  and  distribution  while  governments  should  be  responsible  principally  for
establishing  the  policy,  institutional,  and  regulatory  framework  to  support  sustainable
management of resources. Combating widespread overfishing and the depletion of resources,
increasing degradation of fishing grounds, and poverty among artisanal fishers are key areas for
ADB support.

40. Spatial Planning Act 24/92 provides the framework and legal basis for natural resources

IV. THE PROPOSED PROJECT
A.  Rationale
41. Marine  and  coastal  resources  provide  for  the  welfare  of  60  percent  of  Indonesia’s
population in the coastal plains. However, the resources have not been properly managed and
have been depleted by (i) overfishing and destructive fish production methods; (ii) siltation and
pollution from land-based activities such as aquaculture, agriculture, forestry, industry, and
mining;  and  (iii)  coastal  development  spurred  by  urbanization,  and  increased  tourism  and
industrial development. These activities alter the biological mix of living resources, damage the
ecosystems, and degrade water quality. Past decades have seen continued degradation of
coastal areas. It is becoming increasingly clear that the coastal zones can be protected only if
resource managers adopt some form of integrated coastal zone planning and management
(ICZPM). Effective management will have to include all the systems that contribute to the
stability and biological health of coastal region:  river basins, forests, farms, and upstream urban
areas. Spatial Planning Act 24/92 provides the legal basis for a physical planning framework
within which such integrated development can take place. However, a substantial amount of
institutional  strengthening  will  be  required  for  making  an  inventory  of  the  resource  base,
undertaking the physical planning, achieving transparency in allocation of resources, clarifying
legal  provisions,  giving  recognition  to  traditional  rights  of  local  communities  to  resources,
enhancing institutional capacity to reduce conflicts among users, and enforcing an effective
monitoring, control, and surveillance system.
42. The fall of the New Order Administration in the wake of the recent financial crisis
ushered in a new phase in managing natural resources and the environment in Indonesia.
Recent laws on regional autonomy (Act 22/99) and sharing of revenue by national and regional
governments  (Act  25/99)  paved  the  way  for  increased  decentralization.  Under  the  new
legislation, provincial and district governments should rapidly recognize the need for arresting
further degradation of natural resources and managing it sustainably for the benefit of the State
and the community. The laws give the provinces and districts expanded authority to explore,
exploit and manage the terrestrial and marine wealth within their jurisdiction. The laws also
increase  the  sense  of  ownership  of  natural  resource  at  local  government  level,  provide
enhanced opportunities for community participation, and increase the prospect of transparency
in allocating and using natural resources. However, sustainable management of resources in
the changed context will require capacity building at the local level followed by implementation
of complementary programs/projects addressing related policy and institutional issues. Unless
local planners are able to make proper inventory of the resource base, identify the related
problems  and  issues,  and  work  out  a  plan  for  allocating  and  managing  resources  on  a
sustainable basis and guide the decision-making process accordingly, the resource may be
used for short-term gains with serious implications for long-term viability.
43. The Project provides for capacity building at the local level to effectively carry out the
functions  and  responsibilities  devolved  to  the  regions  for  managing  marine  and  coastal
resources.  It  builds  on  the  lessons  learned  from  previous  projects  and  formulates  a
comprehensive program for expansion of the integrated planning concept in the participating
provinces.
B.  Objectives and Scope
44. The  objectives  of  the  Project  are  sustainable  management  of  marine  and  coastal
resources and biodiversity, and protection of the environment in a decentralized framework of

12
government. The Project includes (i) strengthening local capacity to plan and manage marine
and coastal resources sustainably, (ii) improving the availability of and access to quality spatial
and biodiversity data and information, (iii) improving the legal and regulatory framework for
resource management and compliance, (iv) using ICZPM to identify viable alternative income-
generating activities in coastal zones, and (v) improving socioeconomic and environmental
conditions in selected coastal habitats.
45. The Project will be implemented in following 15 provinces, or such other provinces as
the Government and ADB may agree: (i) North Sumatra; (ii) West Sumatra; (iii) South Sumatra;
(iv) Riau; (v) Bengkulu; (vi) Lampung; (vii) West Kalimantan; (viii) Central Kalimantan; (ix) South
Kalimantan;  (x)  East  Kalimantan;  (xi)  North  Sulawesi;  (xii)  Central  Sulawesi;  (xiii)  South
Sulawesi;  (xiv)  Southeast  Sulawesi;  and  (xv)  West  Nusa  Tenggara.  The  provinces  were
selected  considering  a  range  of  coastal  types  and  ecosystems  and  varying  levels  of
socioeconomic  conditions  in  the  provinces,  and  the  commitment  shown  by  the  provincial
authorities.
46. The  Project  will  provide  for  ICZPM  initiatives  for  a  priority  marine  and  coastal
management area in each province, covering about 2-5 districts. MCMAs were selected in
accordance with criteria given in Appendix 3. The selection criteria combine environmental and
social issues to provide an optimal level of environmental, economic, and social benefits. Of an
estimated 15 million poor living in the 15 project provinces, about 8 million live in the 42 districts,
the whole or part of which will constitute the project MCMAs.14 Ten of the 15 MCMAs have
poverty incidence exceeding 30 percent, against the national poverty incidence of 23 percent.
Malnutrition  rates,  as  measured  against  weight-for-age  for  children  under  the  age  of  five,
exceed 20 percent in most of the districts of the project MCMAs, and exceed 40 percent in
poverty-stricken districts in 10 MCMAs.  Expenditures on food were estimated to be 60-90
percent of all monthly expenditures, with little remaining for nonfood basic needs. Key indicators
of poverty in the 15 provinces and the MCMAs are in Appendix 4. At the beginning of project
implementation, the selected MCMAs will be further reviewed, with involvement of various
stakeholders at regional and local levels. If required, adjustments in their geographic coverage
will be made in consultation with ADB.
47. The project components are (i) coastal marine resources planning and management, (ii)
spatial  data  and  information  management,  (iii)  marine  and  coastal  resources  laws  and
enforcement, and (iv) small-scale natural resources management schemes.
1. Coastal Marine Resources Planning and Management
48. This component will promote ICZPM by improving and strengthening the planning and
management  capacity  of  provincial  and  district  BAPPEDAs  and  selected  sector  agencies
involved in assessing and conserving marine resources. ICZPM is a process of governance and
consists of the legal and institutional framework necessary to ensure that development plans
and  programs  are  prepared  with  the  participation  of  those  affected.  A  planning  hierarchy
involving the sequential development of a strategy plan, zoning plan, management plan, and
action plans, will form the basis of ICZPM activities (Appendix 5). The strategy plan identifies
provincial and district planning issues, establishes the agreed-upon directions and expected

the programs and projects (such as objectives, scope, costs, implementation arrangements,
benefits, etc.) and forms the basis for implementation.

if it is small.

programs, (iii) natural resource accounting and its use for planning purposes, and (iv) priority
area planning at a semidetailed level.
2. Spatial Data and Information Management
51. The planning and management activities will be supported by collecting additional data
and information, and installing hardware and software facilities to facilitate access to data and
information by planners and decision makers. Regional government planners will specify the
thematic data they need for planning, and will contract the supply of data in a specific format,
delivery modes, and timetable. The four subcomponents are: (i) surveys and mapping, (ii)
information technology, (iii) spatial data infrastructure, and (iv) national biodiversity information

planning  issues  or  planning  themes,  for  the  entire  planning  area.  The  major  themes  may
include, but will not be limited to, the following:

d. National Biodiversity Information Network
56. As part of information management, the Project will establish NBIN with the aim of (i)

3.  Legislative Review and Law Enforcement
59. The  component  aims  at  strengthening  the  legal  framework  for  managing  natural
resources,  particularly  marine  and  coastal  resources,  and  improving  the  law  enforcement
regime in the sector. The Project will provide for (i) reviewing existing laws and traditional rights
and practices relating to the management of natural resources; (ii) determining the need to
change existing laws or relevant regulatory mechanisms to promote more effective enforcement
of such laws, or to enact new laws to be consistent with the national guidelines on natural
resources management and to recognize traditional rights; and (iii) assisting the Government in
drafting changes to existing legislation or enacting new ones in consultation with stakeholders.
Priority attention will be given to revising laws regulating fisheries and other marine and coastal
resources, including sustainable use and protection measures for mangroves, coral reefs, and
sea grass areas, and will specifically include laws related to spatial planning and jurisdiction of
relevant ministries and regional governments over coastal lands classified as mangrove forests.
60. To improve the law enforcement regime of integrated resource management, the Project
will help (i) develop appropriate mechanisms for interagency coordination; (ii) institutionalize
procedures and practices for transparency and participation in decision-making processes for
resource allocation and management; (iii) translate environmental protection issues identified in
plans/studies  into  binding  conditions  of  licenses  and  approval;    and  (iv)  develop  effective
institutionalized mechanisms for continuing adequate levels of funding and provide personnel
and other resources for regulatory and law enforcement activities. Resource allocation through
resource consents, resource permits, and licensing will be defined and included in management

planning activities and form a critical implementation mechanism for provincial and district
ICZPM plans.
4.  Small-Scale Natural Resources Management Schemes
61. Complementing capacity building for sustainable management planning, the component
will support implementation of a range of small-scale, priority activities consistent with the
project objectives and the hierarchy of spatial plans. Selected activities will support district and
subdistrict decentralization, particularly devolution of responsibility for resource management.
The schemes will be selected and implemented following a process approach, with active
participation of stakeholders, thus demonstrating the tangible value of ICZPM. Typically the
schemes will (i) involve coastal fisheries resources management (CFRM) including rehabilitation
of damaged fish habitats (i.e., mangroves, coral reefs, and sea grass areas); (ii) improve the
coastal  environment  including  control  of  pollution,  siltation  and  erosion;  and  (iii)  develop
alternative livelihood activities for artisanal  fishers.
62. The activities will be supported by an innovative outreach program of adaptive research
and extension initiatives to identify viable income-generating activities for the coastal community
and to manage coastal ecosystems on a sustainable basis. Research and extension activities
will be conducted by domestic research agencies, technology centers, and NGOs specializing in
coastal fisheries, mariculture, coral reef protection and management, coastal vegetation and
ecosystems. The research and extension topics will be selected from proposals submitted by
the agencies and centers. Criteria for evaluating these proposals are (i) adherence to principles
of  sustainable  management  of  the  marine  and  coastal  resources,  (ii)  responsiveness  to

H. Technical Assistance
93. In Indonesia, development planning and resource management initiatives have largely
been national activities. The provincial and district BAPPEDAs were established in the 1980s,
but  their  actual  function  strongly  focused  on  regional  coordination  of  sector  development

25
initiatives  decided  at  the  national  level.  Some  provincial  BAPPEDAs  have  gained  some
experience in resource planning and management through the ADB-assisted LREP, LREP II,
and MREP, while district BAPPEDAs do not yet have necessary human resources, technical
know-how, and required facilities.
94. Act 22/99 requires a major shift in responsibility for development planning and resource
management from the national level to provincial and district levels. Such decentralization will
require creating local awareness and understanding of the problems and issues involved in
natural  resources  planning  and  management  and  strengthening  of  capacity,  including
mobilization of resources (human, physical, and financial) to match the increased responsibility.
The project provides support to 15 of the 26 provinces and only 42 of about 341 districts to
strengthen resources planning and management capacity, with focus on marine and coastal
resources.  The  Government  needs  to  develop  a  program  for  capacity  building  of  regional
planning and sector agencies nationwide, particularly at district level to cover both terrestrial and
marine resources. The Government has, therefore, requested ADB to provide a TA in preparing
a program for decentralized capacity building for natural resources management.
95. The TA for Capacity Building for Decentralized Natural Resources Management will (i)
analyze  the  implications  of  decentralization  measures  on  the  roles  and  functions  of  the
BAPPEDAs and sector agencies at the provincial and district levels, including an assessment of
human resources, technical know-how, and logistical support in the context of natural resources
management; (ii) evaluate the implications of the existing and evolving regulatory framework for
natural resources management on regional capacities for undertaking resource planning and
management; (iii) provide specific recommendations for viable institutional and organizational
reforms to improve the capacity for decentralized management of natural resources at the
district and provincial levels; (iv) select about five district BAPPEDAs, based on agreed-upon
selection criteria, and implement a pilot capacity building program, following a holistic approach
in  natural  resources  planning  and  management;  and  (v)  make  general  recommendations,

V. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION
A. Benefits
97. The principal project benefits will accrue from enhanced local capacity to plan and
manage the sustainable development of marine and coastal resources, a responsibility that will
soon be devolved by the national Government to regional governments.  Improved planning will
lead  to  rational  and  coordinated  allocation  of  resources  for  development,  emphasizing
sustainable exploitation, protection, and conservation, and improved public consultation and
participation. The physical plans prepared for the priority areas will facilitate identifying and
prioritizing potential investment opportunities for the public and the private sector. Since the
inland  boundary  for  planning  will  be  the  nearest  watershed  divide,  physical  planning  for
significant parts of inland areas will also be undertaken in conjunction with marine and coastal
areas.
98. The development of spatial data infrastructure under the Project will generate quality
data and information on marine and coastal geology and geomorphology; marine and coastal
ecosystems; vegetative cover, land use, and land suitability; urban and industrial developments
in  coastal  zones;  and  social  and  environmental  issues.  Enhanced  legal  protection  and
empowerment of communities to exercise their traditional rights over local marine and coastal
resources,  and  more  effective  law  enforcement  will  result  in  increased  accountability  and
transparent  use  of  resources,  and  reduce  illegal  activities  that  lead  to  environmental
degradation.
99. The small-scale natural resources management schemes will rationalize the use of
coastal resources, and improve the living conditions of disadvantaged coastal communities. The
overall investment costs of the small-scale schemes will amount to less than $1 million in each
province over a period of six years. Despite the small investment size, these schemes and the
associated  capacity-building  initiatives  will  provide  opportunities  for  local  governments  and
communities to have hands-on practice in decentralized planning, and implementation of small
and affordable development initiatives.
B. Financial and Economic Analyses
100. Due  to  the  predominantly  capacity-building  nature  of  the  Project,  the  financial  and
economic analyses were limited to assessing the quantifiable costs and benefits of the small-
scale natural resources management schemes. The Project is expected to generate direct
benefits from the schemes as formulated and prioritized in the action plans of the selected
areas.
101. The investment initiatives that have been identified include coastal fisheries, coastal
environmental improvement, and alternative livelihoods for sustained income generation. For
illustrative  purposes,  four  models  were  developed  to  demonstrate  the  potential  costs  and
benefits of small-scale schemes that were identified by the participating provinces: (i) seaweed
culture development, (ii) sea bass cage culture, (iii) silvofishery development, and (iv) mangrove
rehabilitation  to  control  coastal  erosion.  Details  of  the  financial  and  economic  analyses,
including assumptions and sensitivity analyses, are presented in Appendix 16.
102. The financial internal rates of return (FIRRs) were estimated at about 24 percent for
seaweed culture, 35 percent for sea bass cage culture, and 23 percent for silvofishery activities.
Adjusting  for  economic  prices,  the  economic  internal  rates  of  return  (EIRR)  were

27
correspondingly estimated at about 29 percent for seaweed culture, 41 percent for sea bass
cage culture, 29 percent for silvofishery, and 12 percent for mangrove rehabilitation to control
erosion. The FIRRs are sensitive to reduction in benefits and increases in operating costs, but
generally robust to increases in investment costs. The FIRRs would fall to 12 percent when
expected benefits are reduced by 6 percent for seaweed culture, 8 percent for sea bass cage
culture, and 16 percent for silvofishery. The FIRRs would fall to 12 percent when operating
costs rise by about 7 percent for seaweed culture, 11 percent for sea bass cage culture, and 28
percent for silvofishery. Nonetheless, the risks of reduction in benefits can be minimized through
adoption  of  recommended,  relatively  simple,  and  well-proven  technology,  combined  with
reasonable management practices to avoid undue shortfalls. Output price risks are minimal,
given the steady consumer demand for fish and seafood in the local and regional markets.
C. Environment
103. The Project will have a substantial positive impact on the environment. The preparation
and application of spatial plans based on ICZPM principles will allow systematic assessment of
inland, marine, and coastal resources, and help develop strategies and actions to address
conflicts over resource uses, control the impacts of human intervention on the environment, and
prevent further degradation of the inland, marine, and coastal ecosystems.
104. Controlling  and  managing  upstream  activities  including  industrial  development  and
agricultural  operations  through  appropriate  zoning  will  minimize  downstream  impacts  on
estuaries  and  coastlines.  Consequently,  sensitive  coastal  habitats  such  as  wetlands  and
mangroves  can  be  safeguarded  to  provide  physical  shelters  for  numerous  species  of
shorebirds, crabs, shrimps, fish, and invertebrates. They can also act as a buffer to stabilize
coastal shorelines and protect them from tidal surges and erosion. Likewise, protecting the coral
reef systems will ensure shelter and food for valued species of fish and shellfish, and contribute
to  renewable  marine  resources  and  biodiversity.  Alternative  sources  of  livelihood  and
investments in natural resources management schemes are expected to work in synergy to
achieve strong ownership and partnership among stakeholders, including local communities, in
protecting the natural resources base for sustained exploitation.
D. Social Dimensions
105. Marine and coastal resources provide important sources of livelihood for a large number
of people in coastal zones and small islands. Population pressure and increased economic
activities have frequently resulted in depleted resources, and intensified conflicts in allocations
and uses of resources. This condition is exacerbated by lack of opportunities for alternative
livelihoods.
106. The project initiatives will improve planning and management functions, thus arresting
further  degradation  of  the  natural  resources,  and  allowing  sustainable  exploitation  and
improvements in living standards of coastal and small-island communities. The consultative
planning and management concepts promoted by the Project will increase transparency and
accountability in zoning decisions and management of spatial plans. These plans, along with
increased public access and enforcement, will provide a rational means for preventing and
resolving conflicts among diverse and competing interests, and reconciling the interests of the
general public and the private sector. The management plans will recognize the traditional rights
of  local  communities  in  coastal  land  use  and  environment-friendly  exploitation  of  natural
resources. Collaborative efforts and partnership between government agencies, and NGOs  will
pressure government authorities to become more service-oriented.

28
E. Poverty Impact
107.  A significant portion of the estimated 8 million poor in the 42 project districts are in the
15  MCMAs  for  which  ICZPM  is  to  be  planned  and  implemented  (para.  46).  The  Project
initiatives will benefit these poor through a number of process channels. Improved management
of marine and coastal resources will allow recovery and replenishment of renewable natural
resource assets, and thereby safeguard the sustainability of the income base for the local
governments  and  communities  concerned.  Consultative  and  participatory  processes  that
underpin  zoning  decisions,  management  plans,  and  action  plans  will  empower  local
communities  and  stakeholders  to  prevent  unilateral  decisions  and  abuses  of  power  by
authorities and vested interest groups in allocating and exploiting natural resources. Improving
the regulatory framework related to natural resources with project assistance will enhance the
effectiveness of the plans and allow public endorsement of enforcing penalties and sanctions.
108. Disadvantaged coastal communities will receive direct benefits from targeted small-scale
investment schemes that include rehabilitation of degraded coastal areas and development of
alternative livelihoods. Alternative sources of livelihood based on labor-intensive mariculture,
and  silvofishery  activities  demonstrate  that  significant  employment  and  incomes  can  be
generated  to  ease  pressure  on  capture  coastal  fisheries.  Through  CFRM  initiatives,  the
livelihood resource base for the artisanal fishers can be sustained by protecting fish habitats to
allow recovery of fish stocks and other aquatic resources, rehabilitating mangroves and coral
reefs, and reducing destructive fishing. Emphasis will be on targeting alternative revenue and
employment-generating initiatives in the selected MCMAs where the incidence of poverty is
particularly severe.
F. Risks
109. The risks that could adversely affect the achievement of the project objectives and its
sustainability are (i) uncertainties emanating from the evolving decentralization process and
institutional arrangements at provincial and district levels, (ii) institutionalization of the spatial
planning and ICZPM process in the BAPPEDAs, and (iii) financial resources and cost recovery.
The implications of these issues and risks, and measures proposed for their mitigation are
summarized below.
110. Evolving Decentralization Process. Act 22/99 and Act 25/99 on administrative and
fiscal decentralization are scheduled to become effective on 1 January 2001. This will require
drafting and approval of a range of enabling rules and regulations and reorganization of regional
government  services,  BAPPEDAs,  and  sector  agencies.18  The  national  and  regional
governments are working together to strengthen the regional institutions by redeploying staff
from the related national agencies, commencing in early 2001. While funds are being allocated
in the regional budgets for increased staff resources, the slow pace in enacting enabling laws to
decentralize  functional  and  fiscal  responsibilities  may  delay  the  required  institutional
strengthening process at the regional level. The project design takes into account the possible
delay, and the number of qualified staff for marine coastal resources planning and management
in a participating province during the initial years is based on current staff strength, with a
modest increase in the second half of the implementation period. On that basis, the participating
provinces have expressed commitment to establish a PIU with a specified number of qualified
staff within one month of loan effectiveness (para. 114).
                  
18  ADB has provided assistance in, among others, drafting the enabling laws under TA 3177-INO: Capacity Building
to Support Decentralized Administrative System, for $500,000, approved on 25 March 1999.

29
111. As  the  rules  and  regulations  to  implement  fiscal  decentralization  are  still  being
developed, the national Government undertook to bear full responsibility for the ADB loan and to
provide required counterpart funds throughout the implementation period. Counterpart funds will
be allocated in the national budget as special allocations to the participating provinces (para.
114).
112. Institutionalizing  ICZPM.  Project  sustainability  requires  that  spatial  planning  and
ICZPM processes be institutionalized within the planning functions and responsibilities of the
BAPPEDAs. The incentives for this institutionalization will depend largely on the impacts that
ICZPM plans can make in the priority areas, and the rewards that local governments can derive
from  sustainable  management  of  resources.  The  priority  MCMAs  were  selected  by  local
governments in accordance with agreed-upon criteria that emphasize the need for improving the
environmentally degraded and socially disadvantaged areas. The management plans to be
prepared for priority areas under the Project are expected to underscore the urgency and
definition that are deficient in a conventional plan. Moreover, the reforms and associated fiscal
benefits introduced under Acts 22/99 and 25/99 strengthen the sense of ownership of local
governments  for  natural  resources,  and  provide  a  congenial  environment  for  adopting  a
sustainable approach to resource management in their jurisdiction.
113. Cost Recovery. The spatial information centers of the BAPPEDAs are expected to
become partially self-financing by the end of the Project. Operational costs for maintaining the
provincial information centers, including providing for adequate equipment maintenance and
periodic  replacement,  were  estimated  at  about  $60,000  annually.  This  level  of  funding  is
affordable to the provincial BAPPEDAs. Existing BAPPEDA budget allocations for information
and planning products generally exceeds the requirements for maintaining information centers.
Nonetheless, provision has been made for the services of a business development adviser in
developing a range of value-added information services so as to generate additional revenues
and attain an increasing level of self-financing capability.  The business development adviser
will  also  provide  staff  training  in  marketing  strategies  aimed  at  establishing  within  the
BAPPEDAs an environment that encourages interaction between the public (the client) and
government staff based on accessibility of data and information.

(iv)  Mangrove loss and abandonment (mangrove disappearance [ha/year])

(vi) Deforestation (average percent of degraded forest cover)
(vii) Water  resource  depletion  and  pollution  (groundwater  and  surface  water  and

(viii) Soil erosion and water management degradation
(ix) Susceptibility to natural disasters (storms, tidal waves, earthquakes, floods)
(x) Incidence of poverty (higher than provincial average, equal to provincial average,
below provincial average);

1. Mangrove Rehabilitation and Mariculture in Serei and Bahoi Villages
 1. Serei and Bahoi, two neighboring villages, are located in Likupang subdistrict, North
Sulawesi  Province.  Fringing  the  villages  is  about  200  hectares  (ha)  of  mangrove  areas,
extensively cut for firewood. Only about 35 ha remains with young, short trees. Beyond the
mangroves, the shallow coastal area is covered by a largely undamaged coral reef. The coral
reefs serve as spawning ground for fry of various fish with high economic value for the local
community. Outsiders occasionally come to fish using destructive methods, such as poison and
explosives. The community is against these practices.
2. The  villages  have  a  population  of  1,633  living  in  433  households.  Education
achievement is low, 91 percent did not finish primary school. About 73 percent of the people of
the villages derive their incomes from a combination of upland agriculture and fishing. Another
27 percent depend on small-scale industry and trade. Annual family income from fishing and
agriculture is about Rp3.5 million for an average family of five (less than $100 per capita);
women family members contribute about 25 percent of that income. The villages were classified
as disadvantaged by the former Inpres Desa Tertinggal (IDT) program. Both villages are also
classified as poor by the BKKBN (family planning) program, with 70 percent having an income in
the lowest of the three income groups in the BKKBN program.
3. The community plans to develop a 100-ha mangrove conservation area by enrichment
planting. They also plan to generate supplemental income by growing fry to commercial size in
cages. Placing the cages near the mangroves and corals will encourage villagers to defend their
area  against  explosives  and  poisoning  by  outsiders.  The  work  will  include  community
mobilization,  mangrove  enrichment,  development  of  mariculture,  and  development  of  a
community-based and local government-supported monitoring and surveillance system against
destructive harvesting of marine resources in the area. Total costs are estimated at about
Rp750 million ($93,000), and the implementation period is estimated at three years.

of the fishponds have since been abandoned) and destructive fishing have degraded the coastal
marine environment near the village, causing a substantial decline in fish yields. Consequently,

motivate others to refrain from overharvesting the naturally grown seaweeds.

product. About 50 households will be initially involved, and the activities will include community
mobilization,  technical  support  and  training,  linking  the  community  with  a  rural  financing
institution for seed capital, establishing seaweed farms, and technical institutional support for
postharvest processing and marketing. A NGO will be engaged to assist the community in the
above activities. The scheme is estimated to cost Rp720 million, and will be implemented over
two years.

12. Sulawesi has a long coastline relative to its land area.  Most of the mainland areas are
located less than 90 kilometers (km) from the coast line. Most of the coastal area is dotted with
small islands, many with land area of less than 1.5 square kilometers.  The surface current
during  the  north-west  monsoon  (November-April)  flows  counterclockwise  around  Sulawesi.
Between May and October, no simple current pattern can be determined. The mangrove forests

ponds. The other vegetation types in the coasts include pes-caprae, and barringtonia formation.
Sulawesi coast is rich in coral reefs. Indonesia’s largest coral reef fish habitat, Sangkaran
Archipelago, is located about 80 km from Makasar, the capital city of South Sulawesi Province.
Sulawesi is also rich in marine species diversity which includes many species of crabs, snails,
sea birds, maleo birds, shorebirds, and four endangered turtle species. Coral mining and fishing
systems using explosives and poison have seriously disturbed the coral reef ecosystem.
c. Kalimantan
13. A large part of the Kalimantan coastline is characterized by deltas and swamplands that
produce massive amounts of nutrient to sustain high levels of marine resource productivity in
the  adjacent  estuarine  and  marine  areas.    Some  parts  of  the  coastal  areas  have  rocky

FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES
A.  Scope and Major Assumptions
1. The analyses are limited to assessing the quantifiable costs and benefits of the small-
scale natural resources management schemes. The overall small-scale schemes are expected
to cost less than $1 million in each province over six years. Despite the small investment size,
the small-scale schemes and the associated capacity building initiatives provide opportunities
for local governments and communities to have hands-on practice in decentralized planning and
implementing small and affordable environment-friendly projects.
2. The  types  of  investment  initiatives  identified  range  from  coastal  fisheries,  coastal
environmental  improvement,  and  alternative  livelihoods  that  promote  environment-friendly
practices  for  sustained  income  generation.  For  illustrative  purposes,  four  models  were
developed to demonstrate the potential costs and benefits of small-scale schemes that the
participating provinces identified: (i) seaweed culture development, (ii) sea bass cage culture,
(iii) silvofishery development, and (iv) mangrove rehabilitation to control coastal erosion.
3. The financial and economic analyses were carried out in 2000 constant prices and in the
local currency, rupiah (Rp). The economic analysis is based on a domestic price numeraire.
Adjustments  for  economic  prices  reflect  mainly  the  removal  of  taxes  and  duties,  and  the
application  of  a  shadow  exchange  rate  factor  (SERF)  of  1.11,  equivalent  to  a  standard
conversion factor (SCF) of 0.9. The base financial exchange rate is at $1.00=Rp8,000. The daily
rural wage rates in mid-2000 varied from one place to another, within the range of Rp10,000-
Rp16,000. Given a situation of less than full employment in the rural areas, a shadow wage rate
factor of 0.9 was applied.
4. Financial  farmgate  prices  of  fish  and  shrimp  were  conservatively  estimated  at
Rp4,000/kilogram (kg) for miscellaneous fish, Rp20,000/kg for fresh sea bass, and Rp60,000/kg
for shrimp species of average grades. Farmgate prices of seaweed vary depending on proximity
to processing facilities and destination markets in regional centers. A conservative estimate of
Rp1,400/kg was assumed for seaweed although prices in coastal areas of South Sulawesi have
reached  as  high  as  Rp4,000/kg  depending  on  type,  moisture  content,  and  other  quality
attributes.
B. Seaweed Production
5. Seaweed production offers significant potential for coastal communities to generate
employment and incomes in an environmentally sustainable manner.  Production from culture
technology  has  proved  financially  viable  at  selected  sites  throughout  Indonesia.    Culture
technology is best practiced using floating wooden grid systems and rafts.  Bottom staking of
rope and wire grids can also be culture method, but is applicable only in limited sea areas with
flat, sandy bottoms. As with other mariculture activities, site selection is critical. The need is for
sheltered  areas  with  adequate  water  exchange,  proper  salinities,  good  water  quality,  and
access to local starter stock.
 6. The  usual  culture  species  are  E. cottonii, Gelidiem, Gracelaria, E. spinosum  and
Hypnea. Seaweed is already produced commercially in many areas in Indonesia in response to
an increasing market demand.  Typically, harvesting takes place after firm orders are received
from local traders based in major cities. International buyers do exist, but their presence in rural
Indonesia is still very limited. Therefore the current production is largely for domestic food

low start-up costs for both investment and operations; technically simple operations of a variable

7. An  indicative  model  of  a  family-based  seaweed  production  of  1  hectare  (ha)

24 percent (Table A16.1). Cash funding required for start-up operations is estimated at Rp2.3

expenses. The daily return to a self-employed person is estimated at Rp18,000, which is
significantly  higher  than  the  prevailing  average  rural  wage  rate  of  about  Rp13,000.  The
seaweed farm is expected to generate about 260 person-days of employment annually per
hectare of cultivation for four harvests. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for seaweed
production is estimated at 29 percent.
C. Fish Cage Culture
8. Fish cage culture is practiced widely in Indonesia with a variety of species including sea
bass  (Lates calcarifer),  milkfish  (Chanos chanos),  and  grouper  species  (e.g., Cromileptes
altivelis, Epinephelus fuscoguttatus, etc.). Rearing techniques for each species vary.  Hatchery
production of fry is important in creating a sustainable fish cage culture industry.  This has
historically hampered industry growth. However, recent developments in both hatchery and
rearing technologies, especially for sea bass, have provided for the necessary ingredients for
sustained growth.  Based on the availability of hatchery-bred fry, fish cage culture has opened
up as an attractive, environmentally sound option in coastal Indonesia.  Sea bass, known as
ikan kakap putih in Indonesia, is a popular food fish throughout the country, and local fish with
growing demands are accessible.
9. Positive  features  of  fish  cage  culture  include  environment-friendly  operations,  with
hatchery fry and cage density in any one area limited; potential to provide alternative livelihood
to fishers, thus relieving pressure on natural fisheries resources; and suitability for location in
coastal waters. The fish cage is typically made of net, wooden planks and anchors, for a volume
of about 40 cubic meters. An indicative model of a sea bass cage culture demonstrates that the
scheme is financially viable with FIRR of about 35 percent, offering an attractive alternative
occupation in rural coastal areas. Funding required for start-up operation is estimated at about
Rp14.3 million ($1,800). The daily return to labor is estimated at about Rp30,000, which is triple
the prevailing rural wage rate. The scheme is expected to generate self-employment of 260
days annually for a single-cage operation that can be easily managed by a family. The EIRR is
estimated about 41 percent.
D. Silvofishery
10. In Indonesia, silvofishery is a traditional technology that recognizes the importance of the
mangrove ecosystem and incorporates mangroves into the fishpond system. The traditional
design includes a central platform of mangroves, surrounded by a canal system. The system is
supplied by tidal water flowing through sluice gates. The potential harvest depends on the

11. Positive features of the system include environment friendliness, with limited open water
surface and an intact mangrove ecosystem; attractive alternative income to relieve pressure on
capture fisheries; and appropriateness for coastal waters, which have suffered from depletion of

E. Mangroves and Coastal Erosion Control
12. Mangroves offer natural protection for erosion and abrasion on coastal areas, estuaries
and riverbanks. An illustrative model was developed, based on actual conditions of a coastal
village at Mahakam Delta in East Kalimantan. The delta, on the west of Makassar Strait, covers
about 3,200 square kilometers and is rich in fisheries resources. The village has a population of
about 1,500 in 375 households. Farming and small business activities are the main source of
income for 270 households; the remaining 105 households largely depend on capture fishing for
their livelihood. About 70 percent of the fisher households live along the river. The village has a
shoreline  of  about  4.5  kilometers.  The  mangrove  along  the  riverbank  has  been  severely
damaged by human activities, exposing the riverbank to the effects of water currents and wave
actions. Erosion has occurred, creating a surface land loss at a rate of about three meters a
year. About 10 meters of surface land areas have been washed into the river over the past three
years. Apart from the loss of valuable land, erosion has required the coastal villagers to move
and rebuild their houses nearly every year.
13. The  illustrated  scheme  aims  to  arrest  riverbank  erosion  and  protect  scarce  land
resources and properties of the community by adopting measures such as (i) constructing
erosion protection structures at strategic locations, applying local materials and technologies; (ii)
restoring mangroves along the entire stretch of the affected riverbank; and (iii) informing the
community on preventive measures against bank erosion. The local community has shown
strong interest in the scheme, and willingness to contribute to the rehabilitation investment.
14. The cost of the scheme is estimated at Rp700 million ($87,500), comprising mangrove
replanting, erosion control structures, community mobilization, and nongovernment organization
(NGO) services. The investment is expected to yield an EIRR of about 12.3 percent, drawing
economic  benefits  from  avoided  loses  of  land  and  property  belonging  to  disadvantaged
villagers. The value of land losses was estimated at their current market value/willingness to
pay, as is, without accounting for the potential improvement effects of the Project. Annual
avoidance of property damages was valued conservatively at 15 percent of the average market
value (Rp5.5 million each) of existing houses, excluding movable belongings.
